questions.text: A mother delivers in a rural area under the guidance of a skilled care attendant. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the care provided by the skilled care attendant at birth?

choices.text: Start breastfeeding as early as possible
Cover the baby's head and body
Bathe the baby with warm water
Clear eyes with a sterile swab

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bathe the baby with warm water:

  • This option is incorrect because immediate bathing can lead to hypothermia and is discouraged right after birth. Instead, the focus should be on keeping the baby warm and starting breastfeeding.


Incorrect Options:

Option A - Start breastfeeding as early as possible: Early initiation of breastfeeding, ideally within the first hour of birth, is crucial for the baby’s health. It helps with bonding, provides essential nutrients, and supports the infant's immune system.

Option B - Cover the baby's head and body: Covering the baby’s head and body immediately after birth is important to prevent heat loss and maintain the baby’s body temperature, especially in rural or resource-limited settings.

Option D - Clear eyes with a sterile swab: Clearing the baby’s eyes with a sterile swab helps prevent eye infections, which is part of routine newborn care.

questions.text: What kit would you recommend for a 30-year-old woman who has been experiencing creamy discharge with a fishy odor for the past month, AMSEL's score of 3 out of 4 on the Whiff test, and positive amines in the secretion when tested with 10% KОН?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) Green kit

Explanation: It is indicative of Bacterial vaginosis. The colour-coded kit for vaginitis in the Syndromic management of STI kits is green.

Suraksha Clinics: Integrating STI/RTI Treatment and HIV/AIDS Control
  • Government STI/RTI clinics, branded as "Suraksha Clinics," offer free standardized integrated STD and RTI treatment services at district-level and above healthcare facilities.
  • Under National AIDS Control Program (NACP)

Referral Centers
  • STD Clinics at district, block, and First Referral Unit (FRU) levels act as referral centers for specialized treatment.

Counselling and Condom Distribution
  • Counselling services and high-quality condoms are provided to promote safer sexual practices.
  • Utilizes the expertise of NGOs in providing counselling services at STD clinics.

Training and strengthening existing centers
  • Existing STD clinics in hospitals and medical colleges are strengthened with technical support, equipment,
  • Training for medical staff to manage STDs/RTIs using a syndromic approach.

Pre-packed STI/RTI Color-Coded Kits
  • Free pre-packed kits provided to clinics, centrally procured and distributed through State AIDS Control Societies.

Kit Colors and Conditions

Kit 1 (Grey) (Option D ruled out)

Urethral discharge, anorectal discharge, and cervicitis (Option A)

Kit 2 (Green) (Option C)

Vaginitis

Kit 3 (White) (Non-herpetic)

Genital ulcers

Kit 4 (Blue) (non-herpetic) in patient allergic to penicillin (Option B ruled out)

Genital ulcers

Kit 5 (Red) (herpetic) (Option A ruled out)

Genital ulcers

Kit 6 (Yellow)

Lower abdominal pain (PID)

Kit 7 (Black)

Inguinal bubo

questions.text: In a village with a given population, the total number of live births in a year is 4000. 40 newborns died within the first 7 days of life whereas 40 died due to various causes between 8 to 28 days of life. There were 50 deaths between the age of 1 month to 6 months of life and O of them died in utero. What is the neonatal mortality rate in this population?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) 20

Explanation:

Neonatal mortality rate (NMR) calculation:

  • NMR = (Number of neonatal deaths/Total number of live births) x 1,000
  • Given:
    • Total live births = 4,000, Deaths (0-7 days) = 40
    • Deaths (8-28 days) = 40 NMR ((40+40)/4,000) x 1,000 = (80/4,000) x 1,000 = 0.02 x 1,000 = 20
  • Interpretation: The NMR in this population is 20 per 1,000 live births, indicating 20 deaths within the first 28 days of life per 1,000 live births.

 

Causes of Neonatal deaths:

Most common cause - Birth Asphyxia or Hypoxia

Other causes: Prematurity and low birth weight, neonatal pneumonia, sepsis, congenital anomalies, diarrhea, injuries, and other non-communicable diseases.

Danger Signs: Refusal to feed, lethargic, cold to touch, difficult or rapid breathing, convulsions, persistent vomiting, jaundice at birth, blue color of extremities.

 

Other Neonatal Mortality Indicators:

Early neonatal mortality rate

 

(No. of deaths of children (neonate) 0 – 7 days of life / live births) x 1000)

Late neonatal mortality rate

 

(No. of deaths of children (neonate) 8th – 28 days of

life / live birth) x 1000)

Post neonatal mortality rate

 

(No. of deaths of children (neonate) 29th day - 1 year of life / live births) x 1000)

questions.text: Which one of the following options does not meet the minimum standards for maintaining sanitation in schools and their surroundings in India?

choices.text: Combined doors + windows area = 25% of floor space area
One urinal for 10 students and one latrine for 25 students

questions.solution:
Correct Answer- Option D: One urinal for 10 students and one latrine for 25 students

Explanation:

  • The correct standards are 1 urinal for 60 students and 1 latrine for 100 students.

Healthful School Environment

Aspect

Details

Location

Centrally situated with proper approach roads, away from busy places like roads, factories, and marketplaces. School premises should be fenced and hazard-free.

Site

High, well-drained land. 10 acres for higher elementary schools, 5 acres for primary schools, with additional 1 acre per 100 students.

Structure

Single-story buildings preferred. Exterior walls should be 10 inches thick and heat-resistant

Doors and windows
  • Combined door + window area = atleast 25% of floor area.
  • Cross ventilation should be present. (Option B ruled out)

Classroom

No more than 40 students per room. Minimum 10 sq. ft. per student. (Option C ruled out)

Color of Interior

White interior walls, periodically white-washed.

Furniture
  • Desks should be of ‘minus type’.
  • Chair with proper back rest. (Option A ruled out)

Lighting

Natural light from the left side, not from the front.

Water Supply

Independent source of safe, potable water, continuous supply distributed from taps.

Lavatory

One urinal per 60 students, one latrine per 100 students. Separate facilities for boys and girls. (Option D)

questions.text: The true statement about cow's milk (per 100 gm) when compared to breast milk is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - Option D: High protein

Explanation:

  • Cow's milk does have a higher protein content compared to breast milk. The protein content in cow's milk is generally around 3.2 grams per 100 grams, whereas breast milk contains around 1.1 gram of protein per 100 grams.

Nutritional Component

Human Milk

Cow Milk

Protein Content

Lower, easily digestible

Higher, harder to digest (Option D)

Essential Amino Acids (e.g., cysteine, taurine)

Rich

Lower

Vitamin A & C

Rich

Lower

Iron

Higher bioavailability

Lower bioavailability

Calcium

Adequate, better absorbed

Higher content, less effectively absorbed

Fat Content

Higher proportion of essential fatty acids (e.g., linoleic, alpha-linolenic)

Lower proportion of essential fatty acids

Carbohydrate content

Lactose: 7.5 g/100 mL

Lactose: 5 g/100 mL

Digestibility

Almost completely digested

Much is excreted undigested

Risk of Overloading Kidneys

Low

High (hence dilution recommended)

questions.text: A pregnant woman whose niece lives with her in the same house contracted Varicella. She tested negative for serum antibodies against varicella. What would this mean?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) She is susceptible to chickenpox

Explanation:

  • Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) causes chickenpox (primary infection) and herpes zoster (reactivation).
  • Serum antibodies against VZV indicate prior infection or vaccination.
  • A negative antibody test means she has never had chickenpox nor been vaccinated, making her susceptible to primary varicella infection (chickenpox).
  • This is particularly concerning in pregnancy, as maternal varicella can lead to congenital varicella syndrome or severe neonatal infection.

Varicella Susceptibility and Immunity

Serology

Interpretation

Risk Status

Positive VZV IgG

Past infection or vaccination

Immune to chickenpox

Negative VZV IgG

No prior exposure

Susceptible to chickenpox

Positive VZV IgM

Recent infection

Active chickenpox infection

 

She is immune to zoster (Option A): Incorrect because her negative antibody test means she has never had VZV, so reactivation as zoster is not possible.

She is susceptible to zoster (Option B): Incorrect because zoster occurs due to reactivation of prior VZV infection, which she has never had.

She is immune to chickenpox (Option D): Incorrect because a negative antibody test indicates no immunity to VZV.

questions.text:
According to the 2010-2013 verbal autopsy report, please arrange the following causes of neonatal mortality in descending order, starting from the highest to the lowest.

1. Prematurity and low birth weight

2. Birth injuries and birth asphyxia

3. Congenital anomalies

4. Sepsis
questions.solution:
orrect Option: A) 1 > 2 > 4 > 3

Explanation:

  1. Prematurity and low birth weight: Major contributors to neonatal mortality due to increased risk of complications.
  2. Birth injuries and birth asphyxia: Complications during labor and delivery leading to neonatal death.
  3. Sepsis: Severe infection in newborns, associated with high mortality if not promptly treated.
  4. Congenital anomalies: Structural or functional abnormalities at birth, less common but can still contribute to neonatal mortality.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D are Incorrect.

questions.text:
As per the verbal autopsy report 2010-2013, arrange the most common cause of death among 1-4-year-old children in descending order:

. Diarrhea

2. Pneumonia

3. Malaria

4. Injuries
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) 2>1>4>3

Explanation:

  • Pneumonia: Leading cause of death in children aged 1-4 years, particularly where healthcare and vaccination are limited.
  • Diarrhea: Common cause of childhood mortality, worsened by inadequate water, sanitation, and healthcare.
  • Injuries: Also a leading cause of child mortality, including accidents and trauma, though slightly less common than pneumonia, diarrhea, and malaria.
  • Malaria: Significant cause of death in areas with high mosquito-borne malaria prevalence, especially risky for young children.

questions.text: Compared to a pregnant female, a lactating female would require a higher level of nutrient supplementation for which of the following?
questions.solution:
B)  Calcium

 

Explanation:

 

  • Lactating females require higher calcium supplementation compared to pregnant females due to the significant calcium demand for breast milk production. This is crucial for infant bone and teeth development, as well as maintaining maternal muscle and nerve function.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Vitamin A (Option A): While important, the need for vitamin A doesn't necessarily increase during lactation compared to pregnancy.

 

Iron (Option C): Iron requirements typically decrease slightly during lactation as maternal blood volume decreases postpartum.

 

Folic Acid (Option D): Folic acid's importance remains, but the requirement doesn't notably increase during lactation compared to pregnancy.

questions.text: According to WHO, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - 8

  • According to the WHO, the ideal number of antenatal visits (or Antenatal care contact) is 8.

Schedule of visits:

  • 1st Trimester: 1 visit ( in the first 12 weeks)
  • 2nd Trimester: 2 visits ( at 20 & 26 weeks)
  • 3rd Trimester: 5 visits ( at 30, 34, 36, 38 and 40 weeks)

It recommends that pregnant women have their first contact in the first 12 weeks of gestation, with subsequent contacts taking place at 20, 26, 30, 34, 36, 38, and 40 weeks’ gestation.

questions.text: The pregnancy test kit launched by the government is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - NISHCHAY

  • NISHCHAY is a home-based pregnancy testing kit.
  • It falls under the family planning component of the RMNCH+A strategy of the RCH (Reproductive Child Health) program.

Family Planning Programme:

Mission Parivar Vikas
  • It aims to promote family planning and reduce the population
  • Nayi pahel kit- family planning kit for newlyweds
  • Saas bahu samelan- encourages daughter-in-law and mother-in-law to discuss family planning
  • Saarthi- family planning mobile van

NISHCHAY
  • Home testing UPT provided by ASHA

Jansankhya sthirata kosh
  • Population stabilization fund ADD ON: provides incentives for delaying marriage, birth spacing

Gather approach
  • Contraception counseling method
  • Stands for Greet, Ask, Tell, Help, Explain, and Return

NIKSHAY (Option B): Technology-based surveillance for TB patients (TB DOTS - NTΕΡ).

NIKSUTH (Option C): Technology-based surveillance for Leprosy patients.

AXSHYA (Option D): Nationwide TB initiative funded by the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, TB, and Malaria.

questions.text: When should a primigravida initiate breastfeeding after a normal delivery of a healthy baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Within 1 hour

Explanation:

For a primigravida (first-time mother) delivering a healthy baby through normal delivery, it is recommended to initiate breastfeeding within 1 hour after birth. Early initiation of breastfeeding is crucial because:

  • It helps in the initiation of milk production.
  • The baby receives the first milk, known as colostrum, which is rich in nutrients and antibodies, providing essential protection against infections.
  • Early breastfeeding also promotes bonding between the mother and the baby.

 

After 1 hour (Option B): is incorrect because, as per guidelines, the baby should begin breastfeeding within the first hour of birth, not after it.

After 4-6 hours (Option C): is incorrect. Delaying breastfeeding for this long can lead to problems like poor milk production and inadequate intake by the baby.

After 24 hours (Option D): is incorrect. Waiting for 24 hours is too long, and early breastfeeding is essential for both maternal and infant health.

questions.text: Which is not a part of Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme?
questions.solution:
he Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) Programme is structured around six key components:

  • 6 Beneficiaries- Target groups include children, adolescents, pregnant and lactating women, and women of reproductive age.
  • 6 Interventions- Includes iron supplementation, deworming, BCC (Behavior Change Communication), dietary diversification, testing, and treatment.
  • 6 Institutional Mechanisms- Ensures effective program implementation through policies, supply chain management, training, etc.
  • However, there is no mention of "6 health functionaries" in the official framework, making it the incorrect option.

Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme

Component

Details

Launch Year

2018

Objective

Reduce anemia prevalence across different population groups

6 Beneficiaries

Children (6-59 months, 5-9 years), Adolescents (10-19 years), Pregnant & Lactating women, Women of reproductive age

6 Interventions

Iron supplementation, Deworming, Delayed cord clamping, BCC, Testing & treatment, Dietary diversification

6 Institutional Mechanisms

Political commitment, Supply chain management, Training & capacity building, Monitoring, Convergence, Research & Innovation

Target

Reduce anemia prevalence by 3% per year

 

6 Beneficiaries (Option A): Correct because AMB targets 6 specific groups.

 

6 Interventions (Option B): Correct as AMB includes 6 strategies to combat anemia.

 

6 Institutional Mechanisms (Option C): Correct since it ensures the smooth implementation of AMB.

questions.text: The formula with the numerator being maternal deaths and the denominator being women of reproductive age represents which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Maternal mortality rate:

  • The maternal mortality rate (MMRate) is calculated as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 women of reproductive age (usually defined as ages 15-49) in a given time period. It measures the risk of maternal death in the general population of women of reproductive age.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Maternal mortality ratio: This ratio measures the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births in a given time period. It reflects the risk of death once a woman becomes pregnant, not the general population risk.

Option C - Perinatal mortality rate: This rate measures the number of stillbirths and deaths within the first week of life per 1,000 total births (live births plus stillbirths). It does not relate to maternal deaths.

Option D - Perinatal mortality ratio: This term is not commonly used. If used, it might be mistaken for the perinatal mortality rate, but it does not apply to maternal deaths or reproductive-age women.

questions.text: Given 500 live births, 12 stillbirths, and 9 deaths within the first 7 days, calculate the Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR).
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 18:

  • The Early Neonatal Mortality Rate (ENMR) is calculated as the number of deaths of live-born infants within the first 7 days of life per 1000 live births.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.text:
Calculate the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for the year 2023, given the following events:


	Total women who died: 6
	Total live births: 4000
	Causes of death:
	1 due to road traffic accident (RTA)
	1 due to sepsis
	1 due to obstructed labor
	1 due to eclampsia
	1 due to ectopic pregnancy
	1 due to snake bite
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 100:

  • Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births.
  • Maternal deaths include those caused by complications of pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, excluding accidental or incidental causes.
  • Identifying Maternal Deaths:
  • Maternal deaths: Sepsis, obstructed labor, eclampsia, ectopic pregnancy.
  • Non-maternal deaths: Road traffic accident (RTA), snake bite.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and D are incorrect as given above.

questions.text: What were the goals for Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR) and Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) by 2023?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- 70/30

  • The goal for MMR and IMR by 2023:
    • Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR): Reduce to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
    • Infant Mortality Rate (IMR): Reduce to less than 30 per 1,000 live births.

questions.text: In a population with a total of 4050 births, there are 50 stillbirths, 50 neonatal deaths within the first 7 days, and 150 deaths between 8 and 28 days of life. What is the Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) for this population?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- 50

Explanation:

Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) measures the number of deaths of infants within the first 28 days of life per 1000 live births.

It is calculated as,

Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) = (No. of deaths of children (neonates) 0 – 28 days of life / live births) x 1000)

Calculate Live Births:

  • Live births = Total births - stillbirths
  • Live births = 4050 - 50 = 4000

Determine the Total Number of Neonatal Deaths:

  • Neonatal deaths include deaths within the first 7 days and between 8 and 28 days.
  • Total neonatal deaths = 50 (deaths within the first 7 days) + 150 (deaths between 8 and 28 days) = 200

Calculate NMR:

NMR = (200/4000) x 1000 = 50

questions.text:
Which of the statements about palliative care is true?

A. Disease is the centre of concern

B. The patient is sovereign

C. Death should neither be prolonged nor hastened

D. The aim is to improve the quality of life

E. The intention is to cure

F. Imperative to do something than passively observe
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) B, D, F

Explanation:

Palliative care:

  • It is a specialized medical care, where the main aim is to improve the quality of life and alleviate the suffering of patients.
  • It addresses the physical, psychosocial, and spiritual aspects of patients who have a life-threatening disease with interprofessional team approach
  • Management of symptoms and patient distress is the central focus
  • Care is not limited to a hospital; there are many community clinics and in-home opportunities
  • Hospice care is a form of palliative care specifically designed for patients with a terminal illness and a prognosis of six months or less to live. It focuses on providing comfort and support to patients and their families in the final stages of life, often foregoing curative treatments.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female comes to the STI clinic with minimal vaginal discharge. On speculum examination, erosions are seen on the cervix. Which of the following kit should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Grey

Explanation:

  • The probable diagnosis would be a sexually transmitted infection.
  • There are 7 color-coded STD kits.
  • Kit 1- Grey is given for urethral discharge, cervicitis, and anorectal discharge.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a 2-year-old child gives a history of completing required antenatal vaccinations during her previous pregnancy. Which of the following would you recommend for her current pregnancy?

choices.text: Give a booster dose of TT
Give a booster dose of Td

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Give a booster dose of Td

Explanation:

The Td (Tetanus and Diphtheria) vaccine is recommended as a booster dose during pregnancy, especially if the woman has completed the required antenatal vaccinations previously. In India, the current guidelines suggest giving two doses of Td (Tetanus and Diphtheria) during pregnancy: one at the start of pregnancy and one between 20 to 26 weeks.

  • Tetanus Toxoid (TT) is part of routine antenatal immunization, but the Td vaccine is recommended if there is a history of prior TT vaccination in previous pregnancies, as it also covers Diphtheria.

 

Give a booster dose of TT (Option A): is not correct in this context, as the current guidelines recommend Td (Tetanus and Diphtheria) for booster doses, not TT.

Give 2 doses of TT (Option C): is incorrect because only a booster dose of Td is needed. Giving 2 doses of TT is not the standard recommendation if the woman has completed required antenatal vaccinations in the previous pregnancy.

Give 2 doses of Td (Option D): is not correct because only 1 dose of Td is recommended for the current pregnancy, not two. The second dose of Td is given between 20-26 weeks of pregnancy if the first dose was given early in the pregnancy.

questions.text: The school health programs are managed by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Primary health centre

  • School health programs are managed by the Primary Health Centre (PHC) within their jurisdiction.
  • PHCs are responsible for ensuring school health services, including periodic checkups and health education, in their assigned areas.

 

School Health Services

1. History:

  • Bhore Committee: Launched the concept of school health checkups.
  • Renuka Roy Committee: Recommended school health checkups once every 4 years.

2. Current Recommendation:

  • School health checkups are recommended once every 6 months.

 

School Health Administration

1. Responsibility:

  • Primary Health Centres (PHCs): Responsible for school health services in their respective jurisdictions.

2. Coverage:

  • Each Medical Officer should cover 5,000-6,000 children per year.

3. Village Level:

  • School Health Committees can be established to ensure health services at the village level.

District hospitals (Option B): are higher-level healthcare facilities that provide secondary level care to the population within a district. They primarily focus on advanced medical care and management of more complex health issues.

The sub-center (Option C): Sub-centres provide basic healthcare services at the village level but do not have the capacity to manage school health programs.

Sub-divisional hospitals (Option D): also known as taluka hospitals or community health centres, are healthcare facilities at the sub-district level.

questions.text: What is the most effective indicator for measuring the overall health of a society?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Infant Mortality Rate (IMR):

  • IMR reflects infant health status per 1,000 live births, making it a sensitive indicator.
  • It aids in international comparisons, guiding policy decisions, and monitoring public health programs.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Under 5 Mortality Rate: It's broader, not specific to infants.

Option C - Child Death Rate: It includes older children.

Option D - Maternal Mortality Rate: Focuses on maternal health, not infants.

questions.text: During a routine check-up, a 26-year-old pregnant woman visited the sub centre. Which of the following tests are typically conducted at the sub centre for pregnant women?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Haemoglobin:

  • Typically tested at the sub-centre during pregnancy.
  • Monitors maternal iron levels for anemia detection.
  • Convenient for routine prenatal care at local healthcare facilities.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ultrasound (USG): Typically performed at specialized diagnostic centers, not sub-centres.

Option C - OGTT (Oral Glucose Tolerance Test): Conducted at larger healthcare facilities to screen for gestational diabetes.

Option D - Triple Test: Administered at specialized centers to assess chromosomal abnormalities risk.

questions.text: Sensitive parameter of combined obstetric and pediatric care in the country is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Perinatal Mortality Rate:

  • Measures stillbirths and early neonatal deaths per 1,000 total births.
  • Reflects pregnancy outcomes and care quality.
  • Sensitive to combined obstetric and pediatric care.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Post-neonatal Mortality Rate: Covers deaths after 28 days, not perinatal care.

Option B - Infant Mortality Rate: Includes post-neonatal deaths, not solely perinatal.

Option C - Neonatal Mortality Rate: Only considers deaths within 28 days, excluding stillbirths.

questions.text: What is the dosage of vitamin A given for a 2-year-old baby with keratomalacia?

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by same dose after 24 hours
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 1 week
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 24 hours and after a week
2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D - 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks:

  • This regimen ensures rapid replenishment of vitamin A stores, crucial for treating keratomalacia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by same dose after 24 hours:

  • Immediate dose with no follow-up after 2 weeks.

Option B - 1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 1 week:

  • Lower initial dose and no follow-up within 2 weeks.

Option C - 1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 24 hours and after a week:

  • Immediate and follow-up doses but lacks the critical second dose after 2 weeks.

questions.text: Most common cause of LBW in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Premature birth:

  • In India, the most common cause of Low Birth Weight (LBW) is premature birth. LBW is defined as a birth weight less than 2,500 grams. Premature infants are born before completing the full term of pregnancy and often have lower birth weights.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Smoking during pregnancy: While smoking during pregnancy can contribute to LBW, it is not the most common cause in India.

Option B - Maternal tetanus: Maternal tetanus is not a common cause of LBW.

Option C - Intra-uterine growth retardation: Intra-uterine growth retardation (IUGR) can lead to LBW, but it is not the most common cause in India.

questions.text: What is the additional amount of energy needed on a daily basis during pregnancy? (in Kcalories)
questions.solution:
Correct option. C

  • During pregnancy, there is an increased energy requirement to support the growth and development of the fetus. The additional energy requirement is generally estimated to be around 350 kcal per day. This extra energy intake helps meet the nutritional needs of the mother and supports the healthy development of the baby.

Incorrect options 

Option A. +300 kcal: While a slight increase in energy intake may be beneficial during pregnancy, the recommended additional energy requirement is typically higher, around 350 kcal per day.

Option B. +600 kcal: A 600 kcal increase in energy intake would be excessive and could contribute to excessive weight gain during pregnancy, which is not recommended.

Option D. +520 kcal: The recommended additional energy requirement during pregnancy is around 350 kcal per day, not 520 kcal.
